title: Vance Dinges
text:
Vance George Dinges (May 29, 1915 – October 4, 1990) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="baseball%20player">player</a>. He appeared in 159 <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League</a> <a href="games%20played">games</a> as a <a href="first%20baseman">first baseman</a> and <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> for the <a href="1945%20Philadelphia%20Phillies%20season">1945</a> and <a href="1946%20Philadelphia%20Phillies%20season">1946</a> <a href="Philadelphia%20Phillies">Philadelphia Phillies</a>. The native of <a href="Elizabeth%2C%20New%20Jersey">Elizabeth, New Jersey</a>, threw and batted left-handed; he stood tall and weighed .
Dinges' professional career lasted eleven seasons, 1938 through 1948. He was acquired by the Phillies from the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a> in the 1944 <a href="Rule%205%20draft">Rule 5 draft</a>; Phils' <a href="general%20manager%20%28baseball%29">general manager</a> <a href="Herb%20Pennock">Herb Pennock</a> had previously been the head of the Red Sox' <a href="farm%20system">farm system</a>. He made his MLB debut on <a href="1945%20in%20baseball">April 17, 1945</a>, and <a href="single%20%28baseball%29">singled</a> in his first <a href="at%20bat">at bat</a> off <a href="Curt%20Davis">Curt Davis</a> of the <a href="Brooklyn%20Dodgers">Brooklyn Dodgers</a>. He served as a backup outfielder and first baseman that seasons, appearing in 109 games and <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting</a> .287. He also hit his first MLB <a href="home%20run">home run</a> that April 24, a solo blast off the <a href="New%20York%20Giants%20%28NL%29">New York Giants</a>' <a href="Andy%20Hansen">Andy Hansen</a>. Dinges was named a member of the 1945 <a href="National%20League">National League</a> <a href="1945%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20All-Star%20Game">All-Star</a> squad by <a href="The%20Sporting%20News">The Sporting News</a>. But no midsummer classic was played that season and no official All-Star teams were officially chosen by the two leagues because of <a href="World%20War%20II">wartime</a> travel restrictions
Dinges then split between the Phils and their <a href="Utica%20Blue%20Sox">Utica Blue Sox</a> <a href="Eastern%20League%20%281938%E2%80%932020%29">Eastern League</a> affiliate. He backed up <a href="right-handed">right-handed</a>-hitting first baseman <a href="Frank%20McCormick">Frank McCormick</a> in 26 games and batted .308, slugging his second big-league homer as a <a href="pinch%20hitter">pinch hitter</a> off <a href="Ed%20Bahr">Ed Bahr</a> of the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Pirates">Pittsburgh Pirates</a> on July 12.
In 553 <a href="plate%20appearances">plate appearances</a> and 501 at bats, Dinges collected 146 Major League <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hit</a>s and posted a batting average of .291.
